definition:
Let $\psi(\zeta)$ be a density function of a complex variable satisfying
the Hölder condition (the Lipschitz condition of order $\alpha$)[[^1]]{}
on a smooth closed contour $C$ in the integral $$\begin{aligned}
\Psi(z)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_C\frac{\psi(\zeta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta,\end{aligned}$$
then the limits $\Psi^+(t)$ and $\Psi^-(t)$ as $z$ approaches an
arbitrary point $t$ on $C$ from the interior and the exterior of $C$,
respectively, are $$\begin{aligned}
\left\{ \begin{array}{ll}
\Psi^+(t) \equiv \frac{1}{2}\psi(t)+
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_C\frac{\psi(\zeta)}{\zeta-t}d\zeta, \\ 
\Psi^-(t) \equiv -\frac{1}{2}\psi(t)+
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_C\frac{\psi(\zeta)}{\zeta-t}d\zeta.
\end{array}
\right.\end{aligned}$$ These are the Plemelj[@cite:Plemelj] formulas
[[^2]]{} and the improper integrals in (2) must be interpreted as
Cauchy’s principal values.

[99]{} J. Plemelj, [*Monatshefte für Mathematik und Physik,*]{} vol. 19,
pp. 205- 210, 1908. N. I. Muskhelishvili, [*Singular Integral
Equations,*]{} Groningen: Noordhoff (based on the second Russian edition
published in 1946), 1953.

[^1]: A function $f(\zeta)$ satisfies the Hölder condition on a smooth
    curve $C$ if for every $\zeta_1,\zeta_2\in C$
    $|f(\zeta_2)-f(\zeta_1)|\leq M|\zeta_2-\zeta_1|^\alpha$, $M>0$,
    $0<\alpha\leq 1$. It is clear that the Hölder condition is a weaker
    restriction than a bounded derivative for $f(\zeta)$.

[^2]: cf.[@cite:Musk], where restrictions that Plemelj made, were
    relaxed.
